pythonIGA¶

Plate with a hole¶

Functions to solve the plate with a whole problem.

make_holeplate.make_holeplate(numrefine, disp_solve, plotGrid='')[source]¶

Solve the plate with hole problem with linear elasticity

Parameters

  • numrefine – Refined mesh number to use

  • dispSolve – Boolean, activate the result display

  • plotGrid – “mesh” to superimpose the mesh to the results

Assembly module¶

assembly.build_Flocal(R, Jmod, Fb, p, q, F_local)[source]¶

Build local load vector with volume forces

Parameters

  • R – shape functions

  • Jmod – jacobian from the master element to the geometric space

  • Fb – volume force vector

  • p,q – degrees in U and V directions

  • F_local – loacl load vector

Returns

NOthing but changes F_local

assembly.build_Klocal(dR_dx, Jmod, p, q, K_local, E, nu)[source]¶

Build the local K matrix

Parameters

  • dR_dx – shaper function deriviative at the gauss point

  • Jmod – Jacobian (from the master element to the geometric space) multiplied by the Gauss weight

  • p,q – degrees in the U and V directions

  • K_local – local K tensor

  • E – Youngs modulus

  • nu – poisson’s ratio

Returns

Nothing but changes K_local

assembly.build_shapeFun(e, INC, IEN, xi_tilde, eta_tilde, knot_u, knot_v, p, q, B)[source]¶

Compute the shape function values and derivatives at a gauss point

Parameters

  • e – actual element number

  • IEN – element to node connectivity matrix

  • INC – global to local shape function number connectivity matrix

  • xi_tilde,eta_tilde – gauss point coordinates

  • knot_u,knotV – knot vector

  • p,v – degree in U and V directions

  • B – Control points

Returns

assembly.impose_BC(Ub, K, F, method)[source]¶

Impose Dirichlet boundary conditions (don’t ask me why it’s here)

Parameters

  • Ub – (nb,3) vectors containing the node to be imposed, the dof number (1 or 2) and the displacement value

  • K – global K matrix

  • F – global load vector

  • method – “reduce” or “penalty

Returns

F, Ub_vect, free_coord, fixed_coord

assembly.make_KF(knot_u, knot_v, B, p, q, nel, INC, IEN, gp, gw, nquad, E_coeff, nu_coeff, Fb)[source]¶

Compute the global K and F matrix

Parameters

  • knot_u,knotv – knot vectors

  • B – control points

  • p,q – degrees in U and V directions

  • nel – number of elements

  • INC – globale to local shape function number connectivity matrix

  • IEN – element to node connectivity matrix

  • gp – Gauss points

  • gw – Gauss weights

  • nquad – number of quadratic points

  • E_coeff – Youngs modulus

  • nu_coeff – poissons ratio

  • Fb – volume force

Pressure enforcement module¶

Several functions to compute the stress contribution to the force vector

impose_pres.build_F_BC_alt(R_BC, Jmod_BC, p, F_BC_loc, sig_imp, ctrlpts_BC, ni, dx_dtiltexi, dy_dtiltexi, toImpose)[source]¶

Build the local element load vector

Parameters

  • R_BC – shape function values at gauss point

  • Jmod_BC – actual Gauss point name (bad name…)

  • p – curve degree

  • F_BC_loc – local load vector to be filled

  • sig_imp – imposed stress tensor (2x2 np.matrix)

  • ctrlpts_BC – boundary control points (local numbering)

  • ni – initial node number for the actual element

  • dx_dtiltexi,dy_dtiltexi – vector for pull back from the reference element to the geometric space

  • toImpose – Node tom impose sig_imp to

Returns

Nothing but changes F_BC_loc

impose_pres.build_shape_BC(e, INC, IEN, xi_tilde, BC_knot, p, B)[source]¶

Build the boundary shape function and compute its value at the Gauss points

Parameters

  • e – actual element number

  • IEN – element to node connectivity matrix

  • INC – global to local shape function number connectivity matrix

  • xi_tilde – gauss point coordinate

  • BC_knot – boundary knot vector

  • p – boundary degree

  • B – boundary control points

impose_pres.compute_Fimp_alt(nel, IEN, INC, gp, gw, knot_u, p, ctrlpts_BC, corres_BC, nquad, sig_imp, F, toImpose)[source]¶

Compute the imposed stress contribution on the force vector

Parameters

  • nel – number of elements

  • IEN – element to node connectivity matrix

  • INC – globale to local shape function number connectivity matrix

  • gp – Gauss points

  • gw – Gauss weights

  • knot_u – knot vector of the boundary

  • p – boundary degree

  • ctrlpts_BC – boundary control points

  • corres_BC – correspondence table between the boundary nodes and the global nodes

  • nquad – number of quadratic points

  • sig_imp – imposed stress tensor (2x2 np.matrix)

  • F – load vector

  • toImpose – boundary nodes ID to be imposed the stress

Returns

Nothing, but changes the load vector F

Generate mesh integration rules

mesh_rule.Gauss_rule(nquad)[source]¶

Generate gauss points coordinates and weights in the reference element

Parameters

nquad – number of gauss points (2 or 4 implemented)

Returns

Results display module¶

Displays the results fields by interpolating using the NURBS shape functions

plotNurb.compCoordResVal(paramcoord, xtarg, ytarg, ctrlpts, knotvector_u, knotvector_v, degree_u, degree_v, weights)[source]¶

Compute the difference between target and actual x, y geometric coordinates given the (xi, eta) parametric coordinates, for optimization.

Parameters

  • paramcoord – [xi, eta] coordinates

  • xtarg,ytarg – target coordinates

  • ctrlpts – controlpoints

  • knotvector_u,knotvector_v – knotvectors in u and v directions

  • degree_u,degree_v – shape function degree in u and v directions

  • weights – weight list

Returns

L2 norm of the difference between target and actual (x,y) vectors

plotNurb.findcoord(targ, ctrlpts, knotvector_u, knotvector_v, degree_u, degree_v, weights)[source]¶

Find the (xi, eta) coordinates in the parametric space corresponding to a given (x,y) in the geometric space using constrained optimization.

Parameters

  • targ – [x,y] target

  • ctrlpts – control points

  • knotvector_u,knotvector_v – knot vectors in u and v directions

  • degree_u,degree_v – shape function degree in u and v directions

  • weights – weight list

Returns

the corresponding [xi, eta] coordinates

plotNurb.make_plot_matrix(ctrlpts, knotvector_u, knotvector_v, degree_u, degree_v, resol, weights)[source]¶

Generate a C matrix ‘such that C[i,j,k,l] = R[i,j] (xi[k], eta[l]), to plot fields on a grid

Parameters

  • ctrlpts – controlpoints

  • knotvector_u,knotvector_v – knotvectors in u and v directions

  • degree_u,degree_v – shape function degree in u and v directions

  • resol – plot grid resolution

  • weights – weight list

plotNurb.plotMesh(nel, IEN, nobU, ctrlpts)[source]¶

Plot the isogeometric mesh given the controlpoints and connectivity array

Parameters

  • nel – Number of elements

  • IEN – elements to controlpoint connectivity array

  • nobU – number of nodes in the U direction

  • ctrlpts – control point matrix

plotNurb.plotNode(ctrlpts)[source]¶

Plot the controlpoints

Parameters

ctrlpts – controlpoint matrix

plotNurb.plot_field(SU, SV, SOL, label='', plotGrid='', boundlow=-10000, boundsup=-10000, nobU=0, nel=0, IEN=array([0.]), ctrlpts=array([0.]))[source]¶

Plot a given field on a regular grid

Parameters

  • SU,SV – X, Y coordinates matrix

  • SOL – Field matrix

  • label – Title string

  • plotGrid – ‘mesh’ if mesh is to be superimposed

  • boundlow,boundsup – contour color lower and upper bounds

  • nobU – number of CP in U direction (only if plot mesh)

  • nel – number of elements (only if plot mesh)

  • IEN – Connectivity table (only if plot mesh)

  • ctrlpts – Control points (only if plot mesh)

plotNurb.plot_nurbs(ctrlpts, knotvector_u, knotvector_v, degree_u, degree_v, nel, IEN, toPlot, plotGrid, E, nu, disp_solve, numrefine, meshPrev=array([0.]))[source]¶

Plot the result fields on the domain by generating a regular grid in teh parametric space. Also compute the strain and stress from the displacement field. Exports all the results in files in the SQR_vals directory.

Parameters

  • ctrlpts – control point matrix

  • knotvector_u,knotvector_v – knot vector in u en v direction

  • degree_u,degree_v – shape function degree in u and v directions

  • nel – number of elements

  • IEN – elements to controlpoint connectivity array

  • toPlot – Dictionary containing the fields to plot (dimensions= number of DOFS)

  • plotGrid – Strin, “mesh” will superimpose the mesh, “

  • E – Youngs modulus

  • nu – Poisson ratio

  • disp_solve – Boolean indicating wether the plots should be displayed or not

  • numrefine – Refinement number (only used to name the output files)

  • meshPrev – Previous mesh control points. Use to compare two solutions on two different meshes.

NURBS shape function module¶

Functions to compute NURBS shape function values

simonurbs.BasisFun(i, u, p, U)[source]¶

Returns the value of the basis function i, of degree p with knots U, at point u source: the NURBS book

simonurbs.BasisFunDers(i, u, p, U, n)[source]¶

Compute the basis function and the n-th first derivatives. Source: the NURBS book.

Parameters

  • i – knot span for u

  • u – evaluation point

  • p – basis order

  • U – knot vector

  • n – maximum derivative degree

Returns

matrix ders[p+1,p+1] where ders[i,j] is the value of the i-th derivative of Nj function

simonurbs.compRval(param, xi, eta, ctrlpts, knotvector_u, knotvector_v, degree_u, degree_v, weights)[source]¶

Interpolate a field value at a given point using the NURBS shape function

Parameters

  • param – field values at the control points

  • eta (xi,) – parametric coordinate where to compute the field

  • ctrlpts – control points

  • knotvector_v (knotvector_u,) – knot vectors in u and v direction

  • degree_v (degree_u,) – degrees in u and v directions

  • weights – weight vector for eqch control point

Returns

float field value

simonurbs.lookuptablespan(knotVector, k, plotVector, s)[source]¶

Make a matrix for which A[i] is the knot span in which plotVector[i] lays in. Source: the NURBS book.

Parameters

  • knotVector – knotVector to span

  • k – knotVector length

  • plotVector – parametric coordinate vector to span in the knotVector

  • s – plotVector length

Returns

a matrix contaning the knotvector span for each element of plotVector

Linear system solving module¶

Function to solve the linear system Ku = F

solve.check_symmetric(a, tol=1.0)[source]¶

Check if matrix a is symmetric withing a given tolerance tol (default 1)

solve.solve_KU(K, F, free_dofs, fixed_dofs, Ub_vect, nen, method='reduce')[source]¶

Solve the system Ku = F using the scipy sparse solver

Parameters

  • free_dofs – dofs id where no dirichlet BC was imposed

  • fixed_dofs – dofs id where dirichlet BC was imposed

  • Ub_vect – Dirichlet BC list

  • method – “reduce” (default) for solving only on unconstrained dofs

  • nen – number of nodes

Returns

displacement u and reaction forces f_rea

Geometry generation module¶

Different functions to generates nurbs from a description or from a file

make_geom.build_BC_surf(knotvector_u, ctrlpts, idsurf)[source]¶

Generate a nurbs curve describing one boundary of a nurbs. Source: geoPDE

Parameters

  • knotvector_u – knot vector in u direction

  • ctrlpts – control points

  • idsurf – if of the boundary to be generated

Returns

BC_ctrlpts, BC_knot, BC_corres (correspondence table between the boundary nodes and the global nodes)

make_geom.load_geom(geom_name)[source]¶

Import a NURBS geometry defined by a JSON object with following parameters:

Parameters

  • knotVectorU/V – knot vector list in U and V direction

  • p,q – NURBS order in U and V directions

  • controlPoints – control point (x,y) coordinate list sorted by U

  • weights – NURBS weight associated to each control point

Parameters

  • h – beam thickness

  • L – beam length

Returns

p, q, ctrlpts, knotvector_u, knotvector_v

  • L – Plate length

nurbsLib_handle.refine_knots(p, q, knot_u, knot_v, ctrlpts, n)[source]¶

Parameters

  • p,q – degree in U and V directions

  • knot_u,knot_v – knot vectors in U and V directions

  • ctrlpts – control point matrix

  • n – refinement density number
